items.name: Linux: Maximum number of open file descriptors
items.description: It could be increased by using `sysctl` utility or modifying the file `/etc/sysctl.conf`.

triggers.name: Linux: Configured max number of open filedescriptors is too low
triggers.event_name: Linux: Configured max number of open filedescriptors is too low (< {$KERNEL.MAXFILES.MIN})

items.name: Linux: Maximum number of processes
items.description: It could be increased by using `sysctl` utility or modifying the file `/etc/sysctl.conf`.

triggers.name: Linux: Configured max number of processes is too low
triggers.event_name: Linux: Configured max number of processes is too low (< {$KERNEL.MAXPROC.MIN})

dependencies.name: Linux: Getting closer to process limit
dependencies.expression: last(/Linux server by admin/proc.num)/last(/Linux server by admin/kernel.maxproc)*100>80

items.name: Linux: CPU guest time
items.description: Guest time - the time spent on running a virtual CPU for a guest operating system.

items.name: Linux: CPU guest nice time
items.description: The time spent on running a niced guest (a virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel).

items.name: Linux: CPU idle time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

items.name: Linux: CPU interrupt time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

items.name: Linux: CPU iowait time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

items.name: Linux: CPU nice time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

items.name: Linux: CPU softirq time
items.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

items.name: Linux: CPU steal time
items.description: The amount of "stolen" CPU from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks, such as running another virtual machine.

items.name: Linux: CPU system time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

items.name: Linux: CPU user time
items.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

triggers.name: Linux: Number of installed packages has been changed

items.name: Linux: Free swap space
items.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

items.name: Linux: Free swap space in %
items.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in %.

items.name: Linux: Total swap space
items.description: The total space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

items.name: Linux: System uptime
items.description: The system uptime expressed in the following format: "N days, hh:mm:ss".

triggers.name: Linux: {HOST.NAME} has been restarted
triggers.description: The host uptime is less than 10 minutes.

items.name: Linux: Number of logged in users
items.description: The number of users who are currently logged in.

items.name: Linux: Available memory
items.description:
The available memory:
- in Linux - available = free + buffers + cache;
- on other platforms calculation may vary.

See also Appendixes in Zabbix Documentation about parameters of the `vm.memory.size` item.

items.name: Linux: Available memory in %
items.description: The available memory as percentage of the total. See also Appendixes in Zabbix Documentation about parameters of the `vm.memory.size` item.

items.name: Linux: Total memory
items.description: The total memory expressed in bytes.

items.name: Linux: Memory utilization
items.description: The percentage of used memory is calculated as `100-pavailable`.

triggers.name: Linux: High memory utilization
triggers.description: The system is running out of free memory.

dependencies.name: Linux: Lack of available memory
dependencies.expression: max(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[available],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[total])>0

macros.description: Timeout after which agent is considered unavailable. Works only for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).
This macro is used as a threshold in the interface utilization trigger.
The CPU load per core is considered sustainable. If necessary, it can be tuned.
This macro is used as a threshold in the memory available trigger.
This macro is used as a threshold in the memory utilization trigger.
It filters out `loopbacks`, `nulls`, `docker veth` links and `docker0 bridge` by default.
This macro is used for a discovery of block devices. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for a discovery of block devices. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
The average response time (in ms) of disk read before the trigger would fire.
The average response time (in ms) of disk write before the trigger would fire.
The critical threshold for utilization of the filesystem.
The warning threshold for utilization of the filesystem.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
This macro is used for discovery of the filesystems. It can be overridden on host level or its linked template level.
The critical threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization.

triggers.expression: last(/Linux server by admin/proc.num)/last(/Linux server by admin/kernel.maxproc)*100>80
triggers.name: Linux: Getting closer to process limit
triggers.event_name: Linux: Getting closer to process limit (over 80% used)

triggers.expression: max(/Linux server by admin/system.swap.size[,pfree],5m)<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and last(/Linux server by admin/system.swap.size[,total])>0
triggers.name: Linux: High swap space usage
triggers.event_name: Linux: High swap space usage (less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
triggers.description: If there is no swap configured, this trigger is ignored.

dependencies.name: Linux: Lack of available memory
dependencies.expression: max(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[available],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[total])>0

triggers.expression: max(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[available],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Linux server by admin/vm.memory.size[total])>0
triggers.name: Linux: Lack of available memory
triggers.event_name: Linux: Lack of available memory (<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})

triggers.name: Linux: Load average is too high
triggers.event_name: Linux: Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The load average per CPU is too high. The system may be slow to respond.
